title: 115_hr226
content: The Act is titled the "African Elephant Conservation and Legal Ivory Possession Act." It references the African Elephant Conservation Act and provides a limited exemption for certain African elephant ivory. Section 2203 (16 U.S.C. 4223) is amended to include an exemption for the importation or exportation of raw or worked ivory for museum purposes, without requiring permission from the Secretary. The amendment to Section 2203 allows for the display or return of ivory to a foreign museum or person, importation of ivory lawfully importable before February 24, 2014, and possession of previously lawfully owned ivory in the US. SEC. 4. PLACEMENT OF UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER IN EACH AFRICAN ELEPHANT RANGE COUNTRY. The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of State, may station one United States Fish and Wildlife Service law enforcement officer in the primary United States diplomatic or consular post in each African country with a significant population of African elephants to assist in their protection and apprehend individuals involved in illegal killing. SEC. 5 amends the African Elephant Conservation Act to require certification by the Secretary of the Interior when a country is involved in illegal ivory trade. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of elephant ivory. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of African elephant ivory, allowing for the possession, sale, and transportation of lawfully imported or crafted ivory in the United States. SEC. 7 allows for the importation of sport-hunted African elephant trophies under certain conditions, without prohibiting US citizens or legal residents from doing so if the elephant was taken from a country with an elephant population on appendix II of CITES. It also clarifies that this section does not affect the Secretary's duties to implement CITES or the Endangered Species Act. SEC. 8 of the African Elephant Conservation Act prioritizes financial assistance for projects in ivory producing countries aimed at anti-poaching efforts. It also reauthorizes the Act for the years 2018 through 2022.
